children.value:
npm gets its config settings from the command line, environment
variables, and

command can be used to update and edit the contents
of the user and global npmrc files.
For a list of available configuration options, see
All npm config files are an ini-formatted list of
parameters. Environment variables can be replaced using
prefix = ${HOME}/.npm-packages

Each of these files is loaded, and config options are resolved in
priority order. For example, a setting in the userconfig file would
override the setting in the globalconfig file.

Array values are specified by adding "[]" after the key name. For
example:

key[] = "first value"
key[] = "second value"
files are interpreted as comments when they begin with a

# last modified: 01 Jan 2016
; Set a new registry for a scoped package
@myscope:registry=https://mycustomregistry.example.org
When working locally in a project, a

file in the root of the
project (ie, a sibling of

) will set
config values specific to this project.

Note that this only applies to the root of the project that you're
running npm in. It has no effect when your module is published. For
example, you can't publish a module that forces itself to install
globally, or in a different location.
Additionally, this file is not read in global mode, such as when running

param, if set in the environment
or on the command line)

param, if set above):
This file is an ini-file formatted list of

parameters.
Environment variables can be replaced as above.

This is an unchangeable "builtin" configuration file that npm keeps
consistent across updates. Set fields in here using the

script that comes with npm. This is primarily for distribution
maintainers to override default configs in a standard and consistent
manner.
